sentences: George Allen "Buddy" Miles Jr. (September 5, 1947 – February 26, 2008),  was an American rock drummer, vocalist, composer, and producer.
section: N/A

sentences: He was a founding member of the Electric Flag (1967), a member of Jimi Hendrix's Band of Gypsys (1969–1970), founder and leader of the Buddy Miles Express and later, the Buddy Miles Band.
section: N/A

sentences: Miles also played and recorded with Carlos Santana and others.
section: N/A

sentences: Additionally, he sang lead vocals on the critically  and commercially acclaimed "California Raisins" claymation TV commercials and recorded two California Raisins R&B albums.
section: N/A

section: == Biography and career == | === 1960s: Early career ===

sentences: In 1964, at the age of 16, Miles met Jimi Hendrix at a show in Montreal, where both were performing as sidemen for other artists.

sentences: In 1967, Miles joined Hendrix in a jam session at the Malibu home of Stephen Stills.

sentences: They also went on to play together again in 1968 in both Los Angeles and New York.
section: == Biography and career == | === 1960s: Early career ===

sentences: In the same year, Miles moved to Chicago where he teamed with guitarist Mike Bloomfield and vocalist Nick Gravenites to form the Electric Flag, a blues/soul/rock band.
section: == Biography and career == | === 1960s: Early career ===

sentences: In addition to playing drums, Miles sometimes sang lead vocals for the band, which made its live debut at the Monterey Pop Festival in mid-1967.

sentences: In early 1968, the band released A Long Time Comin', its first album for Columbia.

sentences: Miles played drums on one long jam that was eventually split into two album cuts, "Rainy Day, Dream Away" and "Still Raining, Still Dreaming", with a different song, "1983...

sentences: (A Merman I Should Turn to Be)", edited in between.

sentences: All the songs were written by Miles with Charlie Karp except for the latter.

section: == Biography and career == | === 1990s: Tours and remembering Hendrix ===

section: == Biography and career == | === 1990s: Tours and remembering Hendrix ===

sentences: From 1994 to 2007, Buddy Miles formulated his new version of the Buddy Miles Express in the New York City area, with Charlie Torres on bass guitar and vocals, Rod Kohn on guitar and vocals, the then-longest-standing Buddy Miles Express member and band leader Mark "Muggie Doo" Leach on Hammond B3, background vocals, and keyboards, and Kenn Moutenot on drums and vocals and handling management.
section: == Biography and career == | === 1990s: Tours and remembering Hendrix ===

sentences: They toured nearly nonstop in the United States and overseas, with nearly one thousand concerts and festivals to their credit.
section: == Biography and career == | === 1990s: Tours and remembering Hendrix ===

sentences: In 1997, Miles relocated to Fort Worth, Texas.
section: == Biography and career == | === 1990s: Tours and remembering Hendrix ===

sentences: Soon, he began collaborating with a young guitarist from Dallas named Lance Lopez.
section: == Biography and career == | === 1990s: Tours and remembering Hendrix ===

sentences: The former Band Of Gypsys legend would go on to mentor Lopez, co-producing Lopez's debut album, First Things First, with Grammy-winning producer Jay Newland/Norah Jones.
section: == Biography and career == | === 1990s: Tours and remembering Hendrix ===

sentences: The Lopez album was released independently in 1999.
section: == Biography and career == | === 1990s: Tours and remembering Hendrix ===

sentences: Also playing with the Shadowcasters with members John Vela on guitars, Ray Salazar on Bass, Sparky Montoya on Keys and Johnny Mendoza on drums.
section: == Biography and career == | === 1990s: Tours and remembering Hendrix ===

sentences: Miles was also seen in the Hendrix-family-owned official video release, The Making of Electric Ladyland on Rhino Records.
section: == Biography and career == | === 1990s: Tours and remembering Hendrix ===

sentences: The video featured interviews with the majority of players who were involved in recording the legendary Hendrix album.
section: == Biography and career == | === 1990s: Tours and remembering Hendrix ===

sentences: The video includes footage of Miles playing his drum tracks in the studio against the original multi-track recordings of Hendrix.
section: == Biography and career == | === 1990s: Tours and remembering Hendrix ===

sentences: This lineup also contributed a spirited version of Jimi Hendrix's "Wind Cries Mary" on the Blue Haze, Songs of Jimi Hendrix album in 2001.

section: == Biography and career == | === 2000s: Final albums and unreleased songs ===

section: == Biography and career == | === 2000s: Final albums and unreleased songs ===

sentences: Miles and Leach continued writing new but unreleased music until just days before Miles' passing.
section: == Biography and career == | === 2000s: Final albums and unreleased songs ===

sentences: In 2004, Miles reunited yet again with Billy Cox of the Band of Gypsys to re-record songs from the original 1970 live album with guitarists Eric Gales, Kenny Olsen, Sheldon Reynolds, Andy Aledort and Gary Serkin.
section: == Biography and career == | === 2000s: Final albums and unreleased songs ===

section: == Biography and career == | === 2000s: Final albums and unreleased songs ===

sentences: Until his death, Miles continued to be active musically and performed many shows with proceeds going to help support victims of natural disasters and other charitable causes.

sentences: Miles is credited on sessions with George Clinton/Parliament/Funkadelic.
section: == Biography and career == | === 2000s: Final albums and unreleased songs ===

== Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: Between late September and mid-October 1969, Miles stated that: "Jimi was not happy.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: He felt powerless.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: He couldn't do what he wanted to do".
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: In response, in mid-October 1969, Hendrix founded a short-lived band called Band of Gypsys, which Miles would join.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: Alan Douglas and Stephan Bright were initially brought in to produce their recording sessions, but bassist Billy Cox immediately clashed with the pair, deeming them unworthy.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: Cox eventually stormed out of the sessions after a furious row with Bright and went home to Nashville for two weeks, before being coaxed back.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: At the end of Douglas and Bright's one-and-a-half months together, they had only produced one usable backing track, "Room Full of Mirrors".
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: Consequently, Douglas and Bright resigned, stating pressures from the record label, Hendrix's manager Michael Jeffery, and Hendrix's own "lack of interest".
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: The same day Douglas resigned, Hendrix signed the contract with Bill Graham for the two dates at the Fillmore East.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: First, Hendrix had been talking about a Band of Gypsys "jam" LP since late 1968, after the settlement with Ed Chalpin.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: He also introduced the band as both 'Gypsy Sun and Rainbows' and 'Band of Gypsys' during their Woodstock concert.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: At that time, the two Woodstock LPs were only credited as 'Jimi Hendrix'.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: The recording of the Fillmore East concert was initially a single LP, but additional cuts from the concerts have been released on a double CD, Live at the Fillmore East.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: During the two-and-a-half months before the two nights' worth of recordings for the LP, the band rehearsed and recorded in New York City.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: Hendrix was required to give his next LP to Chalpin to be released by the Capitol Records label, but he had become entangled in litigation concerning the contract with Chalpin's PPX record company that he had signed, his agreement with Jeffery & Chandler prior to the contract, and becoming internationally recognized.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: This fact led to Miles and Billy Cox being hired as full-time employees for the duration of the three-month collaboration called the 'Band of Gypsys'.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: In the end, the band produced the LP for Chalpin and Capitol, as well as a single for Reprise.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: During a one-off charity event for the Moratorium to End the War in Vietnam committee a month later, Hendrix had a minor meltdown on stage.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: Speculations include a possibly drug-related meltdown on stage, as well as an act of sabotage on the part of a very frustrated manager, Michael Jeffery.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: Jeffery was not a fan of the Band of Gypsys, which was claimed as fact by Miles.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: Miles had this to say about the incident years later, stating: "Jeffery slipped [Jimi] two half-tabs of acid on stage as he went on...
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: [Jimi] just freaked out.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: I told Jeffery he was an out-and-out complete idiot...
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: One of the biggest reasons why Jimi is dead is because of that guy."
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: Miles and Jeffery already had a strained relationship eventually, as Jeffery was always uncomfortable with Hendrix's and Miles' close friendship.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: After this one-off charity event at Madison Square Garden in January 1970, Jeffery told Miles that he was fired and the Band of Gypsys was no more.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: Although, Cox, and presumably Miles as well, had already been paid off as full-time salaried employees with a $1,000 bonus for their services the week before.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: While with Hendrix, Miles recorded a number of jams, demos, and songs.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: Over the years, more material recorded at the Fillmore East on New Years 1969–1970 has been issued.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: In 2019, the complete performances from all of the four shows were released on the box set Songs for Groovy Children: The Fillmore East Concerts.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: The original versions of "Stepping Stone" and "Izabella", songs which he recorded for the 1970 single with Cox and Hendrix, have been restored and included on the 2001 compilation Voodoo Child: The Jimi Hendrix Collection.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: Three other songs that were recorded with Cox and Hendrix were later used for early posthumous Hendrix albums, including The Cry of Love and Rainbow Bridge.
section: == Friendship and collaboration with Jimi Hendrix ==

sentences: Additional studio recordings by the trio in various stages of development were released on South Saturn Delta, The Jimi Hendrix Experience box set, Burning Desire, West Coast Seattle Boy: The Jimi Hendrix Anthology, and People, Hell and Angels.

== Death and legacy ==

sentences: Death and legacy ==
section: == Death and legacy ==

sentences: At the age of 60, Buddy Miles died on February 26, 2008, at his home in Austin, Texas, with his family by his side.
section: == Death and legacy ==

sentences: According to his website, he died of congestive heart disease.
section: == Death and legacy ==

sentences: Miles was cremated, and there was no funeral.
section: == Death and legacy ==

sentences: The day before Miles died, he heard Steve Winwood and Eric Clapton playing "Them Changes" at Madison Square Garden through his cell phone.
section: == Death and legacy ==

sentences: "Them Changes" is now part of Clapton's set on tour as a tribute to Miles.
section: == Death and legacy ==

sentences: The UK-based newspaper The Independent ran an almost full-page obituary in its Friday, February 29, 2008, edition.
section: == Death and legacy ==

sentences: Asked how he would like to be remembered by the American music magazine Seconds in 1995, Miles simply said: "The baddest of the bad.
section: == Death and legacy ==

sentences: People say I'm the baddest drummer.
section: == Death and legacy ==

sentences: If that's true, thank you world."
section: == Death and legacy ==

sentences: A memorial concert took place on March 30, 2008, at Threadgill's on Riverside Drive, South Austin that included performances by Bernie Worrell, The Family Stone Project, Doug Pinnick, Cyril Neville, The Sixth Chamber and surviving members of the Buddy Miles Express.
section: == Death and legacy ==
